page.title: 02Landscape around Cilcain (1)
page.content: The high ground in the west of the area, rising to over 500m, forms part of the Clwydian Hills and is underlain by slaty-shales of Silurian age. The hillsides are steep but not rocky. Much of the higher land is moorland or rough-grazing; some land has been used for forestry and some reclaimed to provide better sheep-grazing.The east- ern part of the area is underlain by Carboniferous Limestone, which forms a steep scarp, with rocky outcrops in places, on the east side of the River Alyn. Most steeper slopes are wooded: the flatter land of the valley is mainly hedged fields of grass. The unspoilt nature of the scenic countryside here has recently led the Countryside Commission to designate the whole of the Clwydian Hills (including most this area) as an 'Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty'.
